solution: Since $\overline{BC}\cong\overline{DC}$, that means $\angle DBC\cong\angle BDC$ and $$m\angle DBC=m\angle BDC=70^\circ.$$ We see that $\angle BDC$ and $\angle ADC$ must add up to $180^\circ$, so $m\angle ADC=180-70=110^\circ$. Triangle $ACD$ is an isosceles triangle, so the base angles must be equal. If the base angles each have a measure of $x^\circ$, then $m\angle ADC+2x=180^\circ.$  This gives us  $$110+2x=180,$$ so $2x=70$ and  $x=35.$  Since $\angle BAC$ is one of the base angles, it has a measure of $\boxed{35^\circ}$.
model_solution:
Since we have that the two triangles are isosceles, we have that $\triangle BDC$ is isosceles if and only if $m\angle BCD = m\angle BDC$, and $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles if and only if $m\angle ACD = m\angle CAD$.
Note that $\angle BCD +\angle BDC + m\angle ABC = 180^\circ$, so $m\angle BCD = 55^\circ$.
Since we have that $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles, we have $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD$ and $m\angle ACD = 70^\circ - 55^\circ = 15^\circ$.
Since we have that $\triangle ACB$ is isosceles, we have $m\angle ACB = m\angle BAC$ and $m\angle ACB = 180^\circ - (70^\circ + 15^\circ) = 95^\circ$.
Since we have that $\triangle ACB$ is isosceles, we have that $m\angle BAC = m\angle ABC$ and $m\angle BAC = 70^\circ$.
Since $m\angle ACD + m\angle CAD + m\angle CDA = 180^\circ$ and $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD = 15^\circ$, we have $m\angle CDA = 180^\circ - 2(15^\circ) = 150^\circ$.
Since $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles and we have $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD$, we have $m\angle BAC = 180^\circ - (70^\circ + m\angle CAD)$.
We have that $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles if and only if $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD$, and we have that $m\angle CAD = 15^\circ$ and $m\angle ACD = 70^\circ - 55^\circ = 15^\circ$.
Since $m\angle ACD = m\angle CAD$ and $m\angle ACD = 70^\circ - 55^\circ = 15^\circ$, we have $m\angle CAD = 15^\circ$.
Final Answer: The final answer is 35. I hope it is correct.

full_steps:
Since we have that the two triangles are isosceles, we have that $\triangle BDC$ is isosceles if and only if $m\angle BCD = m\angle BDC$, and $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles if and only if $m\angle ACD = m\angle CAD$.
Note that $\angle BCD +\angle BDC + m\angle ABC = 180^\circ$, so $m\angle BCD = 55^\circ$.
Since we have that $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles, we have $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD$ and $m\angle ACD = 70^\circ - 55^\circ = 15^\circ$.
Since we have that $\triangle ACB$ is isosceles, we have $m\angle ACB = m\angle BAC$ and $m\angle ACB = 180^\circ - (70^\circ + 15^\circ) = 95^\circ$.
Since we have that $\triangle ACB$ is isosceles, we have that $m\angle BAC = m\angle ABC$ and $m\angle BAC = 70^\circ$.
Since $m\angle ACD + m\angle CAD + m\angle CDA = 180^\circ$ and $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD = 15^\circ$, we have $m\angle CDA = 180^\circ - 2(15^\circ) = 150^\circ$.

Since $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles and we have $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD$, we have $m\angle BAC = 180^\circ - (70^\circ + m\angle CAD)$.
We have that $\triangle ACD$ is isosceles if and only if $m\angle CAD = m\angle ACD$, and we have that $m\angle CAD = 15^\circ$ and $m\angle ACD = 70^\circ - 55^\circ = 15^\circ$.

Since $m\angle ACD = m\angle CAD$ and $m\angle ACD = 70^\circ - 55^\circ = 15^\circ$, we have $m\angle CAD = 15^\circ$.
